IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: See form 990 page 2, Part III, Line 1
IRS990.MissionDescription: The Gibbes Museum of Art (GMA) exists to link the art of our past with the art of our future through important and exciting acquisitions and innovative educational exhibitions and programs that preserve, enhance and promote the art of Charleston and the (see Schedule O page 31) American South. Our vision is to be a creative, inspirational leader in the world of southern art by presenting our important historic collections and the emerging art of our time to the broadest possible audience.
IRS990.Description: Curatorial/Collections: The core collection of the Carolina Art Association (CAA) stands as a permanent monument to the far-sighted cultural aspirations of the citizens of Charleston, the birthplace of art in the South. Boasting excellent or unique examples of objects by artists that are considered de rigueur for American art museums, the CAA collection of over 10,000 objects has served as a blueprint for building both public and private American art collections around the world. Passing from one gallery to the next, it is possible to follow the course of art in the South in a unique and comprehensive manner from the early eighteenth century through the present with masterpieces from the collection that are highly sought after for major traveling exhibitions, publications and media productions(see Schedule O page 31) across the country and abroad. Examples include the 2007 international exhibition organized by the Guggenheim Museum entitled Art in America: 300 Years of Innovation and the 2007 WNET/PBS production entitled Oprah's Roots hosted by Harvard professor Henry Louis Gates, Jr. In 2010, the curatorial staff of GMA organized and produced a major traveling exhibition and scholarly catalog entitled The Art of Alfred Hutty: Woodstock to Charleston. Recognized as one of the principal artists of the Charleston Renaissance and the first professional director of GMA, this exhibit will offer the first comprehensive examination of his impact on American art in the South and beyond. As the primary public repository for Hutty's body of work, this catalog and exhibition meet GMA's mission to document, interpret, and present works by American artists working in the American South. Through its annual exhibition schedule students and practicing artists are exposed to American art luminaries. During 2010, interesting and educational exhibitions which appealed to a broad range of visitors (30,000) were presented including: The Charleston Story, Lure of the Lowcountry, Brian Rutenberg:Tidesong, African American Folk Art,Whister's Travels, and more.

Activity2.Description: Education/Public Programs: Since 1905, when GMA opened its doors to the public, the museum has served as a hub for all things artistic in the city of Charleston. From the beginning, the art collection was used to teach future generations through example. Numerous artists benefited including Charleston Renaissance artists Alice R. H. Smith and Elizabeth O'Neill Verner. K-12 and adult art education and enrichment programs continue to be central to the mission of GMA with student participation at 3,500 each year. Art to Go brings art education into the schools to increase understanding of visual expression and creativity through art instruction. This program is provided in schools in low-to-moderate income areas for 400+ students for whom Art to Go may be the students' (see Schedule O page 32) only exposure to the arts. Summer Art Camp provides creative fun for children ages 4 - 12 in 6 one-week classes lead by practicing artists & museum educators. Children explore GMA's galleries for inspiration as they create their own art work. In FY10, 90+ youth participated in camp classes emphasizing the environment, international art, & literature. "Title One Goes" to GMA brings students from Title One schools (69%+ population of poverty level students) to GMA for an interactive guided tour with hands-on activities that engage students to use visual thinking strategies & an inquiry-based approach to art. Visits provide students with the opportunity to experience original artwork as a creative endeavor, cultural artifact, historic document, or literary inspiration. It has been proven that art education promotes self-directed learning, improves school attendance, and sharpens critical and creative skills. 900+ students visited during FY10. Adults also benefit from lecture series and classes. In 2010, beginning with the Women in Art lecture series and culminating with a lecture by Christo (the internationally acclaimed installation artist), GMA's adult educational programs increased its audience three-fold. Collaborations with Charleston Chamber Opera & the Spiritual Ensemble brought music relating to the exhibitions into the museum. An exhibition about life on Daufuskie Island in the 1970s coupled with a performance by the Charleston Spiritual Ensemble brought visitors from Beaufort, Savannah, and other surrounding communities. Collaborations with the College of Charleston & the Junior League of Charleston have increased community visitation with free student admission and quarterly, free Community Days.

Activity3.Description: Visitor and Membership Relations: The Carolina Art Association is a membership organization with approximately 2,000 individuals engaged through either individual membership at $45 to high level donors at $10K or above. Membership services and relations is key to our daily activity and requires close monitoring from website and mass mailings to individual benefits and attention. Additionally, over half of GMA's yearly attendance is tourist-based. The museum store offers the opportunity for visitors to learn more about the museum's art collection and general information about Charleston and its place in the history of American art. The store provides opportunities for the public to obtain prints, scholarly works, and objects relating to the collection and art in general.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The collection of the Association consists of various artworks and is maintained for public exhibition and educational purposes. The collection is the most valuable asset of the Association and the Association provides the resources to ensure the collection is protected and preserved. The collection, which has been acquired through purchases and contributions since the Association's inception, is not recognized as an asset on the Statement of Financial Position in accordance with elections made under Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Purchases of collection items are recorded as decreases in the appropriate net asset classes. During the fiscal year ended June 30, 2010, the Association purchased artwork with a fair market value of $8,063. The value of collection items received is not reported as contributions or accessions in the Statement of Activities. Such gifts received for the year ended June 30, 2010 totaled $36,950. All proceeds from deaccessions must be used for the purchase of artwork. The Association sold artwork during the year ended June 30, 2010, and the proceeds from these sales were $6,233.

The collection of the Association consists of works of art in various media such as painting, sculpture, drawing, photography etc. from the 18th century to the present that relate to Charleston and the American South. The Association exists to link the art of the past with the emerging art of our time through innovative exhibitions, interpretation, and educational programs that preserve and promote the art of Charleston and the American South.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The endowment funds of the Association are permanently or temporarily restricted, or Board-designated for program activities (exhibitions, education, & scholarships), acquisition of art for the collection, and conservation of art in the collection as well as facility costs and operations.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The draft 990 is provided to the Board President, Treasurer, Executive and Finance Committees for review and approval. The approved 990 is provided to all Board members for review prior to submission.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Each year every Board member is provided a copy of the governance documents which includes the Conflict of Interest Policy. At that Board meeting and at the annual Board Orientation Meeting, the policy is reviewed & discussed to identify any possible conflicts.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Annual salary survey compiled by the American Association of Museums is used to determine/document appropriate compensation.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THESE DOCUMENTS ARE NOT MADE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC AT THE PRESENT TIME.
